messages.text: Hi there, is there a way to tell Yao that some gates have fixed parameters, so they don't appear in parameters()? My motivation is to avoid calculating grandients with respect to parameters that are fixed in my circuit. My current solution is to define all constant gates via @const_gate, but this is a bit convoluted when the number of constant gates is large

elements.text: Hi there, is there a way to tell Yao that some gates have fixed parameters, so they don't appear in parameters()? My motivation is to avoid calculating grandients with respect to parameters that are fixed in my circuit. My current solution is to define all constant gates via @const_gate, but this is a bit convoluted when the number of constant gates is large

messages.text: Yes, try wrap the block with `NoParam(block)`

elements.text: Yes, try wrap the block with
NoParam(block)

messages.text: Hello! I have one question. Generally we can define gate like parameterized Rx and Controlled Rx in the quantum circuit. I wonder whether we can define gate in the form like time evolution U = exp(-i \theta X1X2) in the circuit?

messages.text:
No, you can not define the above gates as a rotation gate, instead, you should define it as a time evolution operator.
```julia> using Yao

julia> h = kron(X, X) + kron(Y, Y)
nqubits: 2
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y

julia> time_evolve(h, 0.7)
Time Evolution Δt = 0.7, tol = 1.0e-7
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y


julia> rot(h, 0.5)
ERROR: ArgumentError: Gate type Add{2} is not hermitian or not isreflexive.
Stacktrace:
 [1] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:20 [inlined]
 [2] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:26 [inlined]
 [3] rot(::Add{2}, ::Float64) at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:79
 [4] top-level scope at REPL[5]:1 ```
This is because the rotation gate requires the hamiltonian being reflexive (i.e. h^2 == 1).

elements.text: No, you can not define the above gates as a rotation gate, instead, you should define it as a time evolution operator.

julia> using Yao

julia> h = kron(X, X) + kron(Y, Y)
nqubits: 2
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y

julia> time_evolve(h, 0.7)
Time Evolution Δt = 0.7, tol = 1.0e-7
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y


julia> rot(h, 0.5)
ERROR: ArgumentError: Gate type Add{2} is not hermitian or not isreflexive.
Stacktrace:
 [1] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:20 [inlined]
 [2] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:26 [inlined]
 [3] rot(::Add{2}, ::Float64) at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:79
 [4] top-level scope at REPL[5]:1
This is because the rotation gate requires the hamiltonian being reflexive (i.e. h^2 == 1).

messages.text:
There is an alternative
```julia> reg = rand_state(5)
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 5/5

julia> measure!(ResetTo(bit"00111"), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> measure!(RemoveMeasured(), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> reg
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 0/0```

elements.text: There is an alternative

julia> reg = rand_state(5)
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 5/5

julia> measure!(ResetTo(bit"00111"), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> measure!(RemoveMeasured(), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> reg
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 0/0

messages.text:
Hi everyone!
Using expect' to get the gradient of a parametric circuit that contains a UnitaryChannel Block results in the following error:
```MethodError: no method matching mat_back!(::Type{Complex{Float64}}, ::UnitaryChannel{1,StatsBase.Weights{Float64,Float64,Array{Float64,1}}}, ::Array{Complex{Float64},2}, ::Array{Any,1})```
Is this a known problem? (I'm pretty new with Yao so it might totally be my fault :sweat_smile:)

elements.text:
Hi everyone!
Using expect' to get the gradient of a parametric circuit that contains a UnitaryChannel Block results in the following error:
MethodError: no method matching mat_back!(::Type{Complex{Float64}}, ::UnitaryChannel{1,StatsBase.Weights{Float64,Float64,Array{Float64,1}}}, ::Array{Complex{Float64},2}, ::Array{Any,1})
Is this a known problem? (I'm pretty new with Yao so it might totally be my fault

messages.text: This is not your fault, this is because the adjoint rule for this block has not been implemented in Yao.

elements.text: This is not your fault, this is because the adjoint rule for this block has not been implemented in Yao.

messages.text: It is not trivial to implement the adjoint rule for a unitary channel, because it is probablistic.

elements.text: It is not trivial to implement the adjoint rule for a unitary channel, because it is probablistic.

expect'(matblock(pauli_z),reg)```
resulting in following result but not those gradients
```ArrayReg{10, Complex{Float64}, Array...}

messages.text:
hi everyone, I wonder how to unroll the gradient of batched data?
when I use `expect'` to compute the gradient of a batch of data, it always returns the sum of gradients of each data, how to get those gradients of each data respectively?

elements.text:
hi everyone, I wonder how to unroll the gradient of batched data?
when I use
expect'
to compute the gradient of a batch of data, it always returns the sum of gradients of each data, how to get those gradients of each data respectively?

messages.text: I think you have to turn the batch into a for loop. You do not need to worry about the performance for number of qubits > 15, because the performance of batched and non-batched versions are similar at this scale.

elements.text: I think you have to turn the batch into a for loop. You do not need to worry about the performance for number of qubits > 15, because the performance of batched and non-batched versions are similar at this scale.

messages.text: PennyLane is a nice python package, and they have a lot very nice tutorials, but it’s far less as powerful as Yao since it’s implemented as a pure python warper on other things. So if there are some functionalities that is missing in the ecosystem, we can just implement it. but I think as far as I know, most features are in Julia already, some might need some further polish, but it definitely will be less work than wrapping such a python package into Julia

elements.text: PennyLane is a nice python package, and they have a lot very nice tutorials, but it’s far less as powerful as Yao since it’s implemented as a pure python warper on other things. So if there are some functionalities that is missing in the ecosystem, we can just implement it. but I think as far as I know, most features are in Julia already, some might need some further polish, but it definitely will be less work than wrapping such a python package into Julia

messages.text:
I'd appreciate it, if someone can clear this for me....
I get what NISQ devices are, and they are the short-term future of quantum computers!
What about beyond that? I believe that classical computers are a subset of quantum computers.... you can do all the stuff you can do on a classical computer, in a quantum computer too, _and more!_

elements.text:

messages.text:
I think that Quantum Computers can replace classical ones beyond NISQ era.
But I believe future lies with the one which offers the better trade-off between manufacture cost vs computing power.
Also depends on the algorithms developed for quantum machines, in the future. A breakthrough in "quantum software" might reduce the complexity of making softwares for quantum machines.

messages.text:
> I believe that classical computers are a subset of quantum computers....
that is wrong. Classical computers from a information point of view follow boolean logic which is not reversible (in general). Quantum Computers are

elements.text: I believe that classical computers are a subset of quantum computers....
that is wrong. Classical computers from a information point of view follow boolean logic which is not reversible (in general). Quantum Computers are

messages.text: They are two completely different paradigms

elements.text: They are two completely different paradigms

messages.text:
> you can do all the stuff you can do on a classical computer, in a quantum computer too, _and more!_
_No._ 

think about an "AND" gate, which is not reversible. How can you write it as a unitary?
Hint: you can't, unless you add some additional registers.

I think that you _could_ run an arbitrary classiccal algorithm on a qc if you add sufficiently many registers.
But that's stretching it a lot. And i'm unsure about the resulting requirements.

elements.text: you can do all the stuff you can do on a classical computer, in a quantum computer too,
and more!
No.

think about an "AND" gate, which is not reversible. How can you write it as a unitary?
Hint: you can't, unless you add some additional registers.

I think that you
could

run an arbitrary classiccal algorithm on a qc if you add sufficiently many registers.
But that's stretching it a lot. And i'm unsure about the resulting requirements.

messages.text:
> I think that Quantum Computers can replace classical ones beyond NISQ era.
I don't think they ever will.
It's like saying ' i think GPUs will replace CPUs in next XX years, because they are so much more performant'. That is wrong. They are good at their specialized task, at which the CPU does not shine. But you can't run arbitrary things on them (at least, efficiently).

Same is true for qc

elements.text: I think that Quantum Computers can replace classical ones beyond NISQ era.

I don't think they ever will.
It's like saying ' i think GPUs will replace CPUs in next XX years, because they are so much more performant'. That is wrong. They are good at their specialized task, at which the CPU does not shine. But you can't run arbitrary things on them (at least, efficiently).

Same is true for qc

messages.text:
Then maybe in one sci-fi day 'computing' will be a synonim of quantum 'computing', and all our algorithms will be quantum because Quantum AI (whatever that will be) will be so much better than any classical thing.

But it's hard to make such a prediction.
We still don't fully understand the advantages of quantum algorithms over classical in more than a few cases.

messages.text:
Hmmm… We might not need to write software at some point, thanks to the concept of Software 2.0:upside_down_face:

<@UAJH2818E> Thanks, that was a satisfying answer. Some questions：

> Classical computers from a information point of view follow boolean logic which is not reversible (in general).
> 
Doesn't that directly mean, its a subset of what qc can do？I'm referring more to the outcome here than the process.

Regarding running arbitrary things, like I said, it depends on how much can they develop the classical ones... Moore's law is failing already and the cost is kinda increasing！If they can find a better way to manufacture QC and the software takes care of "simulating" Classical computers, I think hybrid computation is possible on entirely quantum computers

messages.text:
> Is there something a classical computer can do and a quantum computer can't？(Again, I'm referring to the outcome)
I'll turn this question around:
is there anything a quantum computer can do and a classical computer can't?
No. We can simulate them.
It's all about overhead and asymptotical cost.
So your question should be: can we run a classical algorithm with a bounded (polynomial) asymptotical complexity  on a quantum computer?

messages.text: my point is that to implement an irreversible operation on a (fault tolerant) quantum computer, let's say following the circuit model, you need to add ancillas, so that if you just look at the few qubits that encode the information it behaves as if you can apply those irreversible operations

messages.text:
Note that my point above was,

Can quantum computers replace classical ones?
and not, "Can quantum computation replace classical computation?"
With my idea being, if quantum computers can decently perform classical computation, is there any need for classical computers in the future?

elements.text:

Can quantum computers replace classical ones?

messages.text: I do not think the current quantum computing stack can replace classical computing. Because it requires an external classical control system. It is so cumbersome is because it does not care about how difficult to applly a gate, but how much entanglement it can have. Current quantum computing devices aim to solve serveral hard problems rather than replacing classical computing, If there is a device to replace classical computing, it should be classical reversible computing.
